Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards an accurate and illuminating theory of weak interactions between open-shell systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Konrad Patkowski of Auburn University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop a new approach to computing noncovalent interaction energies between open-shell systems - a multireference version of symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT). The unique feature of SAPT is its combination of high accuracy and interpretive power, the interaction energy is obtained as a sum of well-defined contributions corresponding to electrostatics, exchange repulsion, induction, and dispersion. Prof. Patkowski and his group extend the applicability of SAPT to interacting systems with significant static correlation that cannot be described by a single Slater determinant. The newly formulated methods are used to compute and interpret interaction energies involving atmospheric radicals, organic polyradicals, and small molecules adsorbed within metal organic frameworks. The NSF EPSCoR office is also supporting this research.

The knowledge of interaction energies between molecules is critical for our understanding of molecular liquids and crystals, atmospheric reactions, interstellar molecules, and the structure and function of proteins. Similar interactions bind small molecules such as carbon dioxide in the porous environment of metal organic frameworks. Prof. Patkowski and his group develop new methods to compute interaction energies in a way that elucidates the underlying physics of the interaction. The understanding gained in this way helps design new frameworks that can be more effective in gas separation, in particular, in removing carbon dioxide from flue and exhaust gases so that it does not get released into the atmosphere. The new methods are implemented in an open-source computer code that is freely available to other researchers. In addition, Prof. Patkowski and his group are developing hands-on computational chemistry modules within the framework of the Auburn University Summer Science Institute, providing realistic research experience to gifted high-school students and enhancing their awareness of the careers in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has expanded the ways in which computational chemists can describe weak interactions between molecules. These interactions are everywhere: they are the ones that provide subtle attraction between helium atoms to make liquid helium, or the attraction between water molecules to make liquid water and ice crystals. The same interactions are crucial for the processes occurring in living cells, such as protein folding and the interaction of an enzyme with its substrate (or with its inhibitor drug). When weak interactions are modeled using computers, the interaction energy can be calculated as the difference between the energy of two molecules when they are together and when they are apart. This difference is hard to compute accurately because one needs to subtract two very similar quantities, and hard to interpret because the single number cannot tell much about the origins of the interaction. An alternative is to calculate the interaction energy directly, without subtraction, using the method called symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT). An attractive feature of SAPT is that the result is provided as a sum of distinct contributions that can be analyzed one by one to elucidate the physics of the interaction. For example, there is an electrostatic contribution that describes how electrons and nuclei in one molecule are attracted and repelled by electrons and nuclei in another molecule (without shifting the electron density around), and a dispersion contribution that quantifies the weak intermolecular attraction due to the correlated motion of electrons. Overall, this project was aimed at making the interaction energy calculations more robust, more accurate, and more computationally efficient. These goals were achieved primarily by developing, programming, and testing new extensions and variants of SAPT.

To extend the applicability of SAPT to interactions of some particularly challenging systems like polyradicals and transition metal ions, we developed formulas for the most important SAPT contributions for interactions involving multireference molecules that cannot be described by a single electron configuration. Moreover, we proposed a SAPT variant that for the first time can access all spin states of the intermolecular complex, not just the highest one. In this way, we can now estimate (in a quick and qualitatively correct calculation) the splittings between different spin states resulting from the interaction between two molecules with unpaired electrons. We have also increased the accuracy of SAPT by deriving and efficiently implementing the explicitly correlated dispersion energy that gives nearly converged results with only a small basis set used to expand the molecular orbitals. Last but not least, the research in this project has helped establish the best strategies for computing weak interaction energies to the desired level of accuracy by investigating the optimal combinations of electronic structure methods and orbital basis sets. In this way, we made recommendations on how to reliably produce interaction energies at the accuracy required for interpreting high-resolution spectra or for generating data for force field and machine learning development.

Several new computational approaches proposed or extended in this project are already available in the open-source Psi4 quantum chemistry code. We have also contributed to the creation and development of the Psi4NumPy framework, a collection of examples and tutorials that make the computer implementation of new algorithms straightforward, document the best practices and key details in programming quantum chemistry approaches, and provide probably the most interactive educational resource for beginning researchers who want to learn how to code their methods. Psi4NumPy is used by multiple research groups, including ours, to develop new computational chemistry methods and to train the graduate and undergraduate students. In our group at Auburn University, this project has led to 3 completed PhD dissertations and many training and presenting opportunities for the students involved. Last but not least, this award helped fund the Auburn University Summer Science Institute (AU SSI) - an annual weeklong, residential research experience for rising high-school juniors and seniors who are interested in science. Our group has contributed to AU SSI by designing and teaching computational chemistry modules where the students run and interpret simple quantum chemistry calculations using our research computer cluster for number crunching, and the students' iPads (with the WebMO app) as an attractive and intuitive graphical interface.
